Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Extreme Events and Ecological Acclimation: Scaling from Cells to Ecosystems
Award.AbstractNarration:
Forests are vital natural and economic resources that support habitat for plants and animals, protect water quality, offer opportunities for recreation and provide jobs and wood for people. Forests are sensitive to the effects of climate change including drought, shifts in weather, and invasion by insects. Little is known about the effects of repeated droughts brought on by climate change or how these effects occur from the tree cells to entire regional forests.

Droughts in the past decade have occurred across much of the western and southwestern United States. These droughts have led to severe consequences on forests, such as widespread forest die-off. This award will answer a fundamental gap in scientific understanding with profound implications for the future of western U.S. forests. Are trees that survive a severe drought more vulnerable or less vulnerable to the next drought? Over two years, the research will assess water stress and scale these measurements of drought vulnerability from the cell level in individual branches to entire ecosystems across four western States. It will draw on tree-core records, measurements of plant populations, anatomy of tree water transport, and measurements of whole-ecosystem fluxes of carbon and water. The ultimate goal is a predictive framework across different spatial scales that will allow prediction of which forests are most vulnerable and the return frequency of drought that's survivable versus lethal.

This project incorporates an extensive commitment to training of scientists at the undergraduate, graduate, post-doctoral, and early-career levels. The project's research will be directly linked with teaching activities by incorporating findings and projects into five undergraduate and two graduate courses across Northern Arizona University, Princeton University, and the University of Nevada, Reno. The research will enable entire continent wide drought monitoring. The research will develop sensor capacity needed for establishing a continent-wide forest drought-monitoring network. The technology developed can aid land managers with the USFS in managing US Forest Lands. High resolution meteorological and plant water status sensors will be developed and deployed, and measurements of forest canopy cover will be made across a broad spatial scale. In addition, these measurements can also supplement the national USFS information such as the Forest Inventory and Analysis program.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Extensive tree mortality in global forests and woodlands during the last decade has prompted concerns that increasing drought, driven by climate change, may devastate forests in the coming decades, negatively impacting regional ecosystems and dependent local economies. Yet our ability to predict these impacts is limited because of a lack of understanding of how individual drought events interact and how different forest types respond. The current project has sought to resolve two fundamental questions. Does a drought affect tree growth only while present, or does it have effects that last beyond the drought event?  Does a drought leave an ecosystem weaker or stronger in the face of subsequent drought? Using tree ring records from the International Tree Ring Database, we studied the timescales of recovery from drought of different evergreen and deciduous tree species in forests and woodlands worldwide.  In the southwestern U.S., we also examined physiological conditions of trees and the timescale of variation in a key atmospheric drought variable. Lastly, the project developed and deployed new environmental sensor technology, termed the “Internet of Trees,” to monitor tree water use and climate response in near real-time.

A major new understanding from the project is that individual, year-long drought events may slow growth of surviving trees for up to four years after the event ends. The basis for this legacy effect may differ among forest types and may involve drought-induced changes in a tree’s hydraulic system, the amount of leaf area, or the condition of beneficial soil organisms, including fungi.  The project found that southwestern U.S. forests and woodlands were among the ecosystems with the longest periods of slowed growth (4 years) following a drought. An important application of this new knowledge is in models of forest growth and forests’ role in global carbon cycle.  Until now, these models have treated drought as a discrete event and have not considered legacy effects.  Two major scientific publications are published or in review that go into detail on the magnitude and variation of these drought legacy effects and the dynamics of recovery from drought among global forests and woodlands.

            The project has also sought to improve understanding of how atmospheric dryness, also known as vapor pressure deficit (VPD), varies temporally and regionally in the Southwest, specifically in regions dominated by ponderosa pine and piñon-juniper ecosystems that have been hard hit by recent droughts. Using available weather service records, the project found that the typical monthly or seasonally-averaged values of VPD used in many models of forest response to climate conditions mask important variation in VPD that occurs over periods of hours to days. This finding is important because it is this shorter-term variation in VPD, combined with low soil moisture, that is likely crucial to drought-induced mortality of trees and the physiological impacts to surviving trees that slows their growth following drought.  A paper summarizing this VPD study is currently in review in the peer-reviewed literature.

The project has improved understanding of the impacts of past droughts to forests and woodlands in a way that will improve predictions of future droughts in a warming climate and provide the basis for informed actions to mitigate drought impacts to ecosystems and societies.
